seriesJson.title: World of the Paperback
seriesJson.description: This series is dedicated to the discussion of literary topics and of the publication of significant paperbound books.

node.title: Tyrone Guthrie's "A Life in the Theatre"
node.description: This program features Tyrone Guthrie discussing his book "A Life in the Theatre."

node.title: William H. McNeill's "The Rise of the West"
node.description: This program features William H. McNeill discussing his book "The Rise of the West."

node.title: Character types in literature
node.description: This program features a discussion with actress Zohra Lampert about various character types in literature.

node.title: James Drought's "Gypsy Moths"
node.description: This program features James Drought discussing his own "The Gypsy Moths."

node.title: "Kibbutz" and "Children of the Kibbutz"
node.description: This program features Melford E. Spiro discussing his books "Kibbutz" and "Children of the Kibbutz."

node.title: Felix Frankfurter's "The Public and its Government"
node.description: This program features Philip B. Kurland discussing Felix Frankfurter's "The Public and its Government."

node.title: "Three Negro Classics"
node.description: This program features "Three Negro Classics" and its editor, John Hope Franklin.

node.title: Milton Friedman's "Capitalism and Freedom"
node.description: This program features Milton Friedman discussing his own "Capitalism and Freedom."

node.title: Paul Goodman's "Growing Up Absurd"
node.description: This program features Paul Goodman discussing his own "Growing Up Absurd."

node.title: H.E.F. Donohue's "Conversations with Nelson Algren"
node.description: This program features H.E.F. Donohue discussing his own "Conversations with Nelson Algren."

node.title: Martin E. Marty's "The Infidel"
node.description: This program features Martin E. Marty discussing his own "The Infidel."

node.title: Saul Bellow's "Herzog"
node.description: This program features Salvatore R. Maddi discussing Saul Bellow's "Herzog."

node.title: Hugh Nissenson's "A Pile Of Stones"
node.description: This program features Hugh Nissenson discussing his own "A Pile Of Stones."
